‘² P. Sittius of Nuceria, a Roman knight, being heavily in debt, favoured for a time the designs of Catiline, but suddenly. through the agency of P. Sulla, sold his landed property. paid his debts, and went to Spain, but not, as was suspected, with a view to helping Catiline. From Spain he went to Mauretania, and returnin to Rome after the suppression of the conspirac , he was t reatened with a prosecution for being implicate in it. He returned to Mauretania, where he “ played the part of king-maker for eighteen years-’⁹ In the African War of 46 he greatly assisted Caesar, who gave him a kingdom in Numidia, where after Caesar's death, he was treacherously slain by Arabim Masinissa’s son.
